DUBAI, Dec 07 (IPS) - For the first time at COP28, faith has a pavilion alongside science, technology, nations, and philanthropy, allowing religious leaders from all over the world to discuss the potential for using spiritual merits to protect the earth from climate change.

Read the full story, “Faith Pavilion Adds Spiritual Dimension to Climate Crisis Resolution”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Faith Pavilion Adds Spiritual Dimension to Climate Crisis Resolution

articles.description:
NEW YORK, Dec 07 (IPS) - The triple planetary crisis of climate crisis, biodiversity loss, and pollution is a threat to the well-being and survival of millions of people around the world. Corruption, in its many forms, worsens these multiple crises.

Read the full story, “Combating Corruption to Address the Triple Planetary Crises”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Combating Corruption to Address the Triple Planetary Crises

articles.description:
The UN World Health Organization (WHO) on Thursday released its first-ever guidelines on managing chronic low back pain - the leading cause of disability worldwide, that effects an astonishing one in 13 of us.

Read the full story, “Do’s and don’ts for tackling chronic back pain”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Do’s and don’ts for tackling chronic back pain

articles.description:
UN independent human rights experts on Thursday raised concerns about the “dangerous precedent and far-reaching negative consequences” of Russia’s Supreme Court decision declaring the “international LGBT movement and its structural units” as “extremist”.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Russia’s LGBT ban condemned, unprecedented Africa malnutrition crisis, health after childbirth”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Russia’s LGBT ban condemned, unprecedented Africa malnutrition crisis, health after childbirth

articles.description:
The UN Secretary-General called for stronger action to fight the growing challenge of transnational organized crime in an address to the Security Council on Thursday.

Read the full story, “Global cooperation critical to combat transnational organized crime”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Global cooperation critical to combat transnational organized crime

articles.description:
The International Organization for Migration (IOM) and the UN refugee agency (UNHCR), on Thursday, called for urgent action to address the deepening humanitarian emergency in the Americas, as the number of migrants and refugees traversing the perilous Darién jungle crossed an unprecedented half a million this year.

Read the full story, “Protect those on the move using deadly Darién crossing”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Protect those on the move using deadly Darién crossing

articles.description:
Two months to the day since Hamas’ terror attacks in Israel prompted a massive Israeli military retaliation in Gaza, the situation in the war-torn enclave is becoming “apocalyptic” with hostilities making meaningful humanitarian efforts “nearly impossible”, UN humanitarians warned on Thursday.

Read the full story, “Gaza fighting further compromises aid amid near ‘apocalyptic’ conditions: UN humanitarians”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Gaza fighting further compromises aid amid near ‘apocalyptic’ conditions: UN humanitarians

articles.description:
The word “genocide” was first coined by Polish lawyer Raphäel Lemkin in 1944 in his book Axis Rule in Occupied Europe. It consists of the Greek prefix genos, meaning race or tribe, and the Latin suffix cide, meaning killing.

Read the full story, “Stories from the UN Archive: The man who defined genocide”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Stories from the UN Archive: The man who defined genocide

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 07 (IPS) - With COP23 underway, researchers and activists are pointing at the plight of climate migrants.

Read the full story, “COP28: Climate Migrants Rights, Risk-based Labor Polices Under the Spotlight”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: COP28: Climate Migrants Rights, Risk-based Labor Polices Under the Spotlight

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 06 (IPS) - In the spirit of global cooperation and environmental commitment, COP 28 launched a groundbreaking initiative aimed at transforming the building and construction sectors. Titled ‘Buildings and Construction for Sustainable Cities: New Key Partnerships for Decarbonization, Adaptation, and Resilience,’ the initiative marks a turning point in addressing the environmental challenges posed by the construction industry.

Read the full story, “Revolutionizing the Building Sector for Sustainable, Resilient Cities”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Revolutionizing the Building Sector for Sustainable, Resilient Cities

articles.description:
OSLO, Norway, Dec 06 (IPS) - The pulverising of Gaza now ranks amongst the worst assaults on any civilian population in our time and age. Each day we see more dead children and new depths of suffering for innocent people enduring this hell.

Read the full story, “Civilian Deaths in Gaza a Stain on Israel and its Allies”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Civilian Deaths in Gaza a Stain on Israel and its Allies

articles.description:
NEW DELHI, India, Dec 06 (IPS) - We, a global coalition of over 50 civil society and human rights organizations from over 30 countries have co-developed the "Civil Society Manifesto for Ethical AI", a groundbreaking initiative aiming to steer AI policies towards safeguarding rights and deconolonising AI discourse. We question, and we are not the only ones: whose voices, ideas and values matter in AI ?

Read the full story, “Global Civil Society Launches Manifesto for Ethical AI”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Global Civil Society Launches Manifesto for Ethical AI

articles.description: Read the full story, “Beware Carbon Myopia at COP28: Why Climate and Nature Action Must Now Come Together in the Race for a Liveable Planet”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Beware Carbon Myopia at COP28: Why Climate and Nature Action Must Now Come Together in the Race for a Liveable Planet

articles.description:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec 06 (IPS) - A dark cloud is hovering above human existence. It is a fairly illusory cloud haunting our minds and wellbeing, but also an actual, menacing, mostly invisible cloud that covers the Earth’s entire atmosphere. Saturated by greenhouse gases, this global threat increases with every year, threatening all life on Earth, causing increased flooding, extreme heat, draught, wild fires, rising sea levels, food and water scarcity, as well as diseases and mounting economic loss. This misery, caused by human greed, thoughtlessness, and self-aggrandizement, trigger human migration and armed conflicts.

Read the full story, “Art and Climate Change”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Art and Climate Change

articles.description:
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Dec 06 (IPS) - Greater government reliance on consulting companies has greatly enriched them while also undermining state capacities, capabilities, national economies, progress, governance and legitimacy.

Read the full story, “Big Cons: How Consultancy Firms Undermine Governments”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Big Cons: How Consultancy Firms Undermine Governments

articles.description:
More than 90 countries underlined their commitment to UN Peacekeeping during a two-day conference in Accra, Ghana, that concluded on Wednesday.

Read the full story, “Countries uphold commitment to UN Peacekeeping at 2023 Ministerial in Ghana”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Countries uphold commitment to UN Peacekeeping at 2023 Ministerial in Ghana

articles.description:
Hundreds of teenagers from New York schools on Wednesday descended on UN Headquarters to discuss mental health, education, homelessness and systematic racism, as part of the build up to this weekend’s 75th anniversary of Human Rights Day.

Read the full story, “New York City youth give a shout out to human rights worldwide”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: New York City youth give a shout out to human rights worldwide

articles.description:
Secretary-General António Guterres on Wednesday highlighted the importance of the UN’s core humanitarian response fund to deploy quick and strategic resources to global crises globally.

Read the full story, “Guterres urges greater support for UN emergency relief fund”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Guterres urges greater support for UN emergency relief fund

articles.description:
Authorities in Nigeria must investigate a string of deadly airstrikes over the past six years and hold those responsible to account, the UN human rights office, OHCHR, said on Wednesday.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Nigeria airstrikes condemned, supporting Venezuelan migrants and refugees, weapons in Myanmar”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Nigeria airstrikes condemned, supporting Venezuelan migrants and refugees, weapons in Myanmar

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 05 (IPS) - Across the African continent, many first-born children in poor and vulnerable households do not go to school as they spend their school days collecting biomass fuel. The regional average of the amount of time spent collecting firewood is 2.1 hours, robbing women and girls in particular of hundreds of hours in a year and crippling their capacities to engage in learning and productive activities.

Read the full story, “Electrifying Cooking: Decarbonizing Africa's Electricity Grid Towards Net Zero”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Electrifying Cooking: Decarbonizing Africa's Electricity Grid Towards Net Zero

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 05 (IPS) - Women bear the brunt of the climate crisis, and inclusion at both the highest level and in the community is key to mitigating its impact. Today, the announcement of the COP28 Gender Responsive Just Transitions and Climate Action Partnership put women at the centre of climate solutions—with a collective endorsement that symbolized a paradigm shift in global commitment.

Read the full story, “Role of Women Irreplaceable in Management of Natural Resources”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Role of Women Irreplaceable in Management of Natural Resources

articles.description:
YEREVAN, Armenia, Dec 05 (IPS) - Every evening, the smell of Indian food takes over Yerevan's northwestern district of Halabian. Indian workers who left early in the morning are back home.

Read the full story, “A Little India in Little Armenia”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: A Little India in Little Armenia

articles.description:
London/New York, Dec 05 (IPS) - “The one international language the world understands” wrote Eglantyne Jebb, founder of Save the Children, “is the cry of a child,” and the evidence is accumulating that children are not only the innocent victims of conflict whose pleas need to be heard, but also the most vulnerable victims of climate change.

Read the full story, “The Climate Crisis is an Education Crisis”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Climate Crisis is an Education Crisis

articles.description:
BRATISLAVA, Dec 05 (IPS) - A major advocacy group has demanded an overhaul of global drug policies as a landmark report is released showing how governments’ complacency has perpetuated a failed ‘war on drugs’ despite its devastating consequences for millions of people around the world.

Read the full story, “'War on Drugs' Failed and Policies Need Major Overhaul - Report”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: 'War on Drugs' Failed and Policies Need Major Overhaul - Report

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 05 (IPS) - Aditi Agarwal, a brilliant computer science engineer and Gold Medalist, once thrived in the tech world, contributing to innovations at Microsoft. However, she felt a calling to address real-world challenges, particularly those related to carbon emissions and plastic pollution. In pursuit of a nobler cause, she joined a company called Go Rewise, a youth-led initiative in India dedicated to recycling PET bottles through a circular economy approach.

Read the full story, “Taking Charge Against Plastic Pollution in India”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Taking Charge Against Plastic Pollution in India

articles.description:
GAZA, Palestine, Dec 05 (IPS) - The 7-day ceasefire brought respite to everyone; hostages were reunited with their families and desperately needed aid went into Gaza. We need more of this; all hostages released and considerably more aid and protection for Palestinian civilians.

Read the full story, “Nowhere is Safe in Gaza -- and Nowhere Left to Go”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Nowhere is Safe in Gaza -- and Nowhere Left to Go

articles.description:
JOHANNESBURG & TASHKENT, Dec 05 (IPS) - Successful city planning, which takes place with the involvement of citizens, is the hallmark of the creation of sustainable cities, the International Conference on Demographic Resilience heard.

Read the full story, “People, Planning Behind Sustainable City Management”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: People, Planning Behind Sustainable City Management

articles.description:
UNITED NATIONS, Dec 05 (IPS) - The language used in the Treaty of the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons (TPNW) is unambiguous on its focus of the grave humanitarian impact of nuclear weapons. The TPNW also recognizes the influence of the public conscience “in the furthering of the principles of humanity as evidenced by the call for total elimination of nuclear weapons”.

Read the full story, “The Intergenerational Impact of Nuclear Testing in Polynesian States”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Intergenerational Impact of Nuclear Testing in Polynesian States

articles.description:
DUBAI, Dec 05 (IPS) - Food and agriculture is a top agenda item at UNFCCC COP28, as the world considers how to tackle the climate impacts of what we eat and how we produce it. The stage has been set for COP28 to be a “food COP”, but for commitments to translate to action, it must also be a “farmers’ COP”.

Read the full story, “Why the UN COP28 Climate Talks Must Serve Farmers to Achieve a Just Transition”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Why the UN COP28 Climate Talks Must Serve Farmers to Achieve a Just Transition

articles.author: Suzanne Kelly
articles.description:
SUBSCRIBER+EXCLUSIVE REPORTING — As the new era of fifth generation (5G) mobile communications advances, China remains steadfast on dominating the field. That poses a national [...] More 
The post Who’s Really Winning the Global 5G and Cloud Computing Infrastructure Race? appeared first on The Cipher Brief.
articles.title: Who’s Really Winning the Global 5G and Cloud Computing Infrastructure Race?
Turn Your Rising Home Equity Into Cash You Can Use
Dream Big with a Home Equity Loan
Want Cash Out of Your Home? Here Are Your Best Options

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: Britain paid Rwanda an additional 100 million pounds in April for the economic development and growth of the country. This payment, which was not previously disclosed, is on top of the 140 million pounds paid last year. The British government also anticipates an additional payment of 50 million pounds next year as part of the same fund. The payment is separate from the treaty signed to revive the deportation scheme for asylum seekers, which was ruled to violate human rights laws.
articles.title: UK made additional payment to Rwanda, says unrelated to deportation scheme

articles.description: Europe News: KYIV: Ukraine on Thursday said it had tested transporting trucks across the Polish border using trains, in an attempt to bypass a month-long blockade .
articles.title: Ukraine moves trucks over Polish border by train to bypass blockade

articles.description: Lori Vallow Daybell, sentenced to life in an Idaho prison for murdering her two youngest children and another woman, pleaded not guilty in Arizona to charges of conspiring to kill her estranged husband and her niece's ex-husband. Her trial is scheduled for April 4. Keith Terry, Vallow Daybell's attorney, did not immediately return a phone call and email seeking comment. Vallow Daybell's niece's ex-husband, Brandon Boudreaux, reported an attempted shooting, linking it to the case.
articles.title: Mom convicted of killing kids in Idaho pleads not guilty to Arizona murder conspiracy charges

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: In a disturbing incident at Farley's East, an Oakland coffee shop, a Jewish customer was denied restroom access after raising concerns about antisemitic graffiti. The video, posted by StopAntisemitism, quickly went viral. Three Farley's East employees prevented the customer from entering the restroom, citing private property rights. The staff expressed support for 'Free Palestine' and the male worker sarcastically remarked about history. StopAntisemitism called for the termination of the employees, while Farley's East acknowledged the incident and took corrective measures.
articles.title: Antisemitism in California: Jewish woman denied access to restroom in café

articles.description: The European Union is expected to produce less meat, wine, and sugar due to health, environment, and animal welfare concerns. The EU will focus on growing more protein crops like soybeans and pulses. The production of cereals and oilseeds will be limited by climate change and pesticide restrictions. Meat production in the EU is projected to decrease by almost 5%, with a significant decline in beef and pork output. Additionally, there will be a decrease in per capita consumption of beef and pork.
articles.title: EU meat, wine and sugar output seen waning in decade ahead

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: In a deepening standoff between House Republicans and Hunter Biden, the GOP warns of contempt charges if the president's son fails to appear for a closed-door deposition scheduled for December 13. Hunter Biden, facing pressure from an impeachment inquiry seeking ties to his father's business dealings, insists on public testimony, citing concerns about selective leaks. The exchange escalates as Republicans assert the non-negotiable nature of their subpoena, challenging Hunter's assertion of manipulation in closed-door sessions.
articles.title: Republicans warn of contempt charges as Hunter Biden refuses deposition

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Former US president Donald Trump, along with his two eldest sons, returned to court for the New York civil trial on fraud allegations. Trump, a frontrunner for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination, has consistently criticized the trial, characterizing it as unfair. They are accused of inflating the value of their real estate assets to secure more favorable bank loans and insurance terms. Trump attended the trial as a spectator, expressing his discontent and describing the proceedings as a "very corrupt trial.
articles.title: Trump returns to NY court for fraud trial, calls it 'corrupt witch hunt'

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Representative Jim Banks introduces the SAFE Adoption for Every (SAFE) Home Act to counter the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) rule prioritizing LGBTQI+ acceptance in adoptive homes. The bill aims to prevent child welfare agencies from denying prospective adopters based on their refusal to comply with a child's LGBTQ status. Banks criticizes the Biden administration for hindering children from finding loving homes and argues that the focus on a child's sexual orientation or gender identity overlooks the concerns of parents opposing irreversible sex change procedures on minors.
articles.title: Biden's LGBTQ adoption rule faces resistance from Republican leader

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: A professor, Anthony Polito, whose job application was rejected recently, carried out a shooting at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas (UNLV), killing three people. The incident occurred in the Lee Business School building and was similar to the 2017 Mandalay Bay incident. The swift response from university police detectives neutralized the threat and prevented further loss of life. The victims' identities remain undisclosed, and investigations are ongoing to determine the motive behind the attack. The UNLV campus has canceled classes and a basketball game, raising concerns about campus safety and the need to address gun violence.
articles.title: Las Vegas gunman turns out be disgruntled professor who wasn't hired

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: The Republican presidential debate in Alabama saw former UN Ambassador Nikki Haley face scrutiny from fellow candidates Ron DeSantis and Vivek Ramaswamy. DeSantis accused Haley of not supporting a ban on gender-affirming medical care for transgender youth. Ramaswamy targeted her with corruption accusations. Haley defended herself and mocked her rivals. Meanwhile, former Governor Chris Christie criticized candidates for not taking on absent front-runner Donald Trump. The debate revealed divisions within the party regarding Trump, and candidates are aware of the need for a breakout moment in the upcoming Iowa caucuses.
articles.title: Trump criticism takes center stage amid intra-party strife in GOP debate

articles.description: Europe News: WARSAW: Poland has given the green light for the construction of 24 new small modular reactor (SMR) units across six sites, executives of the company .
articles.title: Poland approves construction of SMR nuclear units at six sites

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Iran and Cuba announced their commitment to enhancing relations in a joint statement in Tehran. They emphasized the need for cooperation to counter the economic challenges posed by U.S. sanctions. The two countries expressed their shared opposition to the system of domination. Seven memorandums of understanding and cooperation were signed, covering sectors such as science and technology, health, agriculture, energy, mining, communications, and medicine. Meanwhile, the United States charged a former U.S. Ambassador to Bolivia, Victor Manuel Rocha, with spying for Cuba over a span of 40 years.
articles.title: Iran and Cuba join hands to confront US sanctions

articles.description: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak appeals to his Conservative Party to support his plan to send asylum seekers to Rwanda. He warns that further toughening of the legislation could collapse the whole scheme. Sunak faces challenges from lawmakers on the right wing of the party who want Britain to quit international treaties for its own migration policy. The immigration minister's resignation and the possibility of a leadership challenge add to the pressure. The UK PM is trying to revive the economy and shore up party support for the legislation.
articles.title: UK PM Sunak warns Rwanda migration plan will collapse without party unity

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Republican candidate Nikki Haley clashed with Florida Governor Ron DeSantis over her opposition to the Florida education bill (HB 1557), which restricts classroom discussions on gender and sexuality for children. DeSantis criticized Haley for her stance on age restrictions for gender-related procedures, questioning her suitability for the presidency. Haley disputed the characterization, reiterating her support for parental responsibility in such matters. The debate resurfaced Haley's previous critiques of experimental transgender interventions for children and her dissatisfaction with Florida's 'Don't Say Gay' bill.
articles.title: Nikki Haley uses leftist slur in presidential debate on Florida education bill

articles.description: Russia's FSB security service detains a Belarusian man for blowing up two trains in Siberia on the orders of Ukrainian intelligence services as part of a sabotage campaign against Russia's critical infrastructure. The attacks occurred in Russia's Buryatia region on Nov. 29 and Nov. 30, targeting the Severomuysky Tunnel and the Chertov Bridge. The Belarusian man confessed to installing explosive devices on the trains, following instructions from a Belarusian based in Lithuania working for Ukraine. These attacks have caused temporary blockage of traffic amidst a series of sabotage attacks on Russian transport and infrastructure objects.
articles.title: Russia detains man it accuses of blowing up trains at Ukraine's behest

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Former Jacksonville Jaguars employee Amit Patel is facing charges of embezzling over $22 million through wire fraud in a scheme involving the team's virtual credit card program. Patel, who served as the coordinator of financial planning and analysis, allegedly exploited his authority to divert funds for luxury purchases, including a condominium, luxury vehicles, and a high-value watch. He is also accused of using the stolen money for online gambling. If convicted, Patel may be required to forfeit the stolen funds and assets acquired through the fraudulent activities.
articles.title: Jaguars employee accused of embezzling $22 mn to fund lavish lifestyle

articles.description: Defence Minister Rajnath Singh, on a visit to Tamil Nadu to assess the cyclone-hit state, stated that Prime Minister Narendra Modi is distressed by the loss of lives and is personally overseeing the response. Singh has been directed by PM Modi to personally monitor the situation. The central government has released the first installment of the State Disaster Response Force share and approved a center funding of Rs 500 crore for urban flood management activities.
articles.title: PM Modi is distressed, personally overseeing response: Rajnath Singh during visit to cyclone Michaung-hit Tamil Nadu

articles.description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson returns for second day of testimony in public inquiry into Covid-19 pandemic. Johnson admits mistakes in handling crisis and lack of urgency in response. Testimony reveals government's failure to raise alarm earlier and implement lockdown. The inquiry is designed to uncover the lessons of Covid-19 to help officials better respond to future pandemics. Johnson's reputation further tarnished by scandals, including parties at Downing Street offices. Covid-19 death toll exceeds 232,000.
articles.title: Former UK leader Boris Johnson returns for second day of Covid-19 inquiry testimony

articles.description: China's President Xi Jinping is all set to visit Vietnam next week to smoothen the relationship between the two countries. While making the announcement, Beijing's foreign ministry said that the president will start his official visit next week on Tuesday. The Chinese president was invited by Vietnam's top leaders Nguyen Phu Trong and Vo Van Thong, foreign ministry spokesperson Hua Chunying said in a statement. Xi's trip came after a visit by Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi.
articles.title: China's Xi to visit Vietnam next week

articles.description: Russian lawmakers set the date for the country's 2024 presidential election, moving Vladimir Putin closer to a fifth term. The election is scheduled for March 17. Putin, eligible for two more terms, has not yet announced his candidacy but is expected to do so soon. The election is expected to be a formality as Putin has established tight control over the political system. The few potential challengers are either imprisoned or living abroad.
articles.title: Russian lawmakers set presidential vote for March 17, 2024, clearing a path for Putin's 5th term

articles.description: NEW YORK: Former President Donald Trump declined to rule out abusing power if he returns to the White House after Fox News Channel host Sean Hannity a.
articles.title: Donald Trump won’t rule out abusing power as President

articles.description: Middle East News: RIYADH: Russian President Putin on Wednesday said ties with Saudi Arabia were at an “unprecedented level” as he began a hastily arranged meeting in Ri.
articles.title: Putin hails Saudi ties as he meets the crown prince

articles.author: Naomi Canton
articles.description: Samir Shah, named by the UK government on Wednesday as its choice for the post of BBC chairman, had moved to Britain from India as an eight-year-old a.
articles.title: Samir Shah in past criticised BBC on lack of ‘plurality of voice’

articles.description: Israeli officials accuse Hamas fighters of committing widespread sexual violence against women, including rape, mutilation, and murder. The international social justice community is criticized for its silence on these atrocities. A presentation at the UN headquarters provides evidence and testimonies from witnesses. Hamas denies the allegations, citing Islamic principles. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights has requested access to investigate, but Israel has not responded. US President Biden condemns the reported cruelty.
articles.title: Rape, mutilation & worse: Accounts of Hamas sexual crimes come to fore

articles.description: German train drivers will stage a fresh strike starting Thursday evening, escalating their dispute over working conditions. The GDL union called on freight train drivers to strike from 6:00 pm Thursday and passenger train drivers from 10:00 pm. This is their second walkout in weeks. At the heart of the dispute is GDL's demand to reduce working hours to 35 hours a week without salary cuts, which Deutsche Bahn has refused. The strike jeopardizes the future of the railway and staff recruitment.
articles.title: German train drivers to stage fresh strike

articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin visits the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia, offering to discuss energy cooperation, the Middle East conflict, and the Ukrainian crisis. Putin faces an arrest warrant from the International Criminal Court over the war in Ukraine. The UAE has close ties with Russia and serves as a key avenue for Russia to bypass Western sanctions. Putin aims to boost Russia's profile as a power broker in the Middle East and challenge the US. He meets with Iranian President Raisi and participates in international efforts to negotiate a settlement to the Israel-Hamas war.
articles.title: Russia's Putin is visiting the UAE and Saudi Arabia, seeking to bolster Moscow's Mideast clout

articles.description: A special court in Nepal will sentence Samsul Hoda and Brij Kishor Giri, convicted for plotting a failed terror attack on an Indian train, on December 14. They were charged with murder and money laundering. The court revealed that Hoda, the mastermind, had links with Pakistani nationals and received money from ISI to carry out his plans. The bomb planted in the train did not explode. Hoda murdered two Indian nationals after his plan failed. The court will decide the jail sentence and fine, equivalent to their transferred money, on December 14.
articles.title: Nepal court to pronounce sentence on December 14 against 2 convicted for plotting failed terror attack in India

articles.description: A cargo ship named One Orpheus, flagged in Singapore, broke down in Egypt's Suez Canal and collided with the Mansi Bridge. The incident occurred in a newly expanded section of the waterway, where there are two separate shipping lanes. The extent of the damage to both the ship and the bridge is unclear. However, traffic through the canal was not disrupted, and four tugboats have been dispatched to move the cargo ship. This incident adds to a series of accidents in the crucial Suez Canal, which serves as a vital link for global trade.
articles.title: Cargo ship breaks down in Egypt's Suez Canal and crashes into a bridge

articles.description: The United States is imposing sanctions on 15 Mexican individuals accused of involvement in importing fentanyl into the country. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen announced this during her visit to Mexico City. The US Treasury targeted a network of individuals and entities affiliated with the Beltran Leyva Organization cartel to disrupt the supply of fentanyl. Yellen highlighted that fentanyl is the leading cause of death for people aged 18 to 49 in the United States. She emphasized the need for cooperation between the US and Mexico to tackle the fentanyl crisis.
articles.title: US Treasury sanctions network for role in fentanyl import

articles.description: DUBAI: The US Navy shot down a drone that originated from a part of Yemen controlled by the Houthi group on Wednesday morning, a US defense official t.
articles.title: US Navy downed drone originating from Houthi-controlled part of Yemen: Official

articles.description: Europe News: MOSCOW: A pro-Kremlin Ukrainian politician who defected to Russia was found dead outside Moscow on Wednesday, Russian news agencies reported citing lo.
articles.title: Pro-Kremlin Ukrainian politician found dead near Moscow

articles.description: The Islamabad court rejected Imran Khan's request to withdraw his appeal, preventing him from moving it to the Lahore High Court. This is a setback in his efforts to overturn the decision that would disqualify him from running in next year's elections. Khan had appealed against the Election Commission of Pakistan's finding that he unlawfully sold state gifts. The court has not yet decided on whether the ECP's decision should be overturned. Khan remains embroiled in court cases since his ousting as prime minister.
articles.title: Pakistan court rejects former PM Khan's request to withdraw appeal and shift case to separate court

articles.description: Suella Braverman, who was dismissed from her position as home secretary by British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, dealt a new setback to her ex-boss. She cautioned that, under Sunak's leadership, the Conservative Party is at risk of "electoral oblivion" unless there is swift action to intensify efforts against illegal immigration. In her inaugural formal speech since being ousted from the Cabinet last month, the Member of Parliament of Goan origin called on Sunak to implement stringent legislation enforcing the Rwanda strategy for the deportation of illegal migrants to the East African nation.
articles.title: Sacked Suella Braverman warns UK PM Rishi Sunak of 'electoral oblivion'

articles.description: The head of the election monitoring group, Grigory Melkonyants, is being kept in prison until mid-April next year, accused of cooperating with an "undesirable organization." The court extended his pre-trial detention by three months. Golos, labeled "a foreign agent" by the justice ministry, has deployed observers at polling stations and documented electoral abuses. Allies of Melkonyants accuse the authorities of unjustly detaining him to avoid election scrutiny. The Kremlin denies interfering in court cases.
articles.title: Head of Russian election monitoring group to be kept in jail until vote is over: Moscow court

articles.description: NEW DELHI: Flanked by four Russian jets, President Vladimir Putin arrived in the Middle East on Wednesday in a rare trip abroad during which he will d.
articles.title: Putin's Gulf tour: A strategic shift in Russia-Ukraine war?

articles.description: The UK is set to name lifelong television industry veteran Samir Shah as chairman of the century-old British Broadcasting Corp.Shah, 71, who was previously a director on the BBC’s board and has held roles at the corporation leading political and current affairs television, will be announced in the role on Wednesday, according to a person familiar with the discussions. He’s currently chief executive officer of British production company Juniper Communications. He takes over from Richard Sharp, who resigned after an official inquiry found Sharp breached rules by failing to fully disclose ties to the UK’s Conservative Party leadership.
articles.title: UK to name Samir Shah as BBC chairman after sharp controversy

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Prince Harry declines invitation to the Duke of Westminster's wedding, avoiding potential clash with brother Prince William. The wedding of Hugh Grosvenor and Olivia Henson, set for June 7 at Chester Cathedral, could have been the first meeting between Meghan Markle and Kate Middleton since the Queen's funeral. Hugh Grosvenor chose Prince William to attend over Prince Harry. Duke of Westminster has close ties to the royal family, including Prince William and Prince Harry. Prince Harry and Meghan Markle remain silent amid tensions fueled by Omid Scobie's book.
articles.title: Harry opts out of this royal wedding to avoid Meghan's and Kate's clash

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Scientists have discovered a massive water mass in the Atlantic Ocean called the Atlantic Equatorial Water. This water mass blends distinct water masses along the equator due to ocean currents. The discovery, published in the journal Geophysical Research Letters, completes the understanding of fundamental water masses across the World Ocean. The Atlantic Equatorial Water was identified using data from the Argo program, which consists of self-submerging floats. This finding will enhance scientists' understanding of the ocean's mixing processes and global transport of heat, oxygen, and nutrients.
articles.title: Scientists discover giant water mass in Atlantic

articles.description: The Bank of England on Wednesday said its multiple interest-rate hikes aimed at cooling high inflation would prolong a cost-of-living crisis but stressed UK retail banks could contain the fallout. The BoE's Financial Policy Committee (FPC) said in a report that almost five million UK homeowners would see mortgage repayments soar over the next three years. Retail banks tend to pass on BoE rate hikes, hitting customers whose home loans come with variable rates and those whose fixed-term deals are expiring.
articles.title: Bank of England warns on fallout from rate hikes

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: In a heartbreaking turn of events, Life at Sea Cruises abruptly canceled a three-year global luxury cruise, leaving passengers, including Keri Witman, in disbelief. Witman, head of marketing agency Clever Lucy, had meticulously organized her life, selling her home and signing a short-term lease for the $38,500 room. The cruise faced delays in its departure date and complications securing the AIDAaura ship. The cruise company announced refunds in monthly installments from December 1 until February 2024, but passengers remain stranded.
articles.title: Ohio woman sells home for $32,000 luxury cruise that got cancelled

articles.description: Middle East News: Israel forces stormed southern Gaza's main city on Tuesday in what they called the most intense day of combat in five weeks of ground operations again.
articles.title: Israel storms main city of south Gaza, killing scores

articles.description: A passenger bus lost control in Hamtic town, Antique province, and plunged into a ravine, killing at least 16 people and injuring 12 others. The accident occurred on a mountain road known for accidents. The driver, who was among the casualties, lost control of the bus, which then smashed onto a concrete railing and fell into the ravine. Rescuers, including police and army troops, worked overnight to extricate the victims.
articles.title: At least 16 dead and 12 injured as passenger bus falls off ravine in central Philippines

articles.description: US President Joe Biden praised Liz Cheney's warning about the threat of a second Trump term. He also mentioned the Atlantic magazine, Washington Post, and New York Times for issuing similar warnings. Biden cited Trump's extreme language on the campaign trail, comparing it to Adolf Hitler's rise in the 1930s. Despite facing criminal trials, including one for election subversion, Trump is narrowly ahead in opinion polls. Some Democrats have called for Biden to step aside for a new candidate.
articles.title: US President Joe Biden 'not sure' he'd be seeking reelection if not for Donald Trump

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Doug Olson of Mill Woods, Edmonton, stumbled upon a small meteorite while cleaning out his rain gutters this spring. The Menisa meteorite, as it is now named, weighs 33 grams and is only the 18th ever found in Alberta. The discovery began when Olson heard a loud thud on his roof and found the small rock while clearing out his rain gutters. The meteorite is composed of iron, nickel, and chondrule, a grey material. A portion of it is now part of the University of Alberta's collection
articles.title: Edmonton resident discovers rare meteorite in rain gutter

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Conservative MP Bob Seely plans to introduce a bill to strip Prince Harry and Meghan Markle of their royal titles, citing damage to the monarchy's reputation. The proposed Titles Deprivation 1917 Act Amendment Bill draws inspiration from historical precedents and would allow a parliamentary vote to advise the Privy Council on removing titles. This move follows controversies surrounding Omid Scobie's book, which allegedly names King Charles III in a comment about Prince Archie's skin tone.
articles.title: Race row gets bigger : Meghan and Harry could soon lose Royal titles

articles.description: Middle East News: WASHINGTON: In a rare punitive move against Israel, the State Department said Tuesday it will impose travel bans on extremist Jewish settlers implicat.
articles.title: In rare action against Israel, US says extremist West Bank settlers will be barred from America

articles.description: Elon Musk, the billionaire owner of the social network X, shared a video Tuesday in which Argentina's President-elect Javier Milei says equality should never come before freedom, in a sign of how some notable conservatives are closely watching the incoming libertarian head of state. "We need to talk, Elon," Milei replied on X, formerly Twitter. This is not the first time that Musk, the founder of SpaceX and CEO of Tesla, has expressed support for Milei on social media. "Prosperity is about to come to Argentina," Musk wrote when Milei won the election runoff on Nov 19.
articles.title: Argentina's President-elect Milei replies to Musk's interest: 'We need to talk, Elon'

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson renews call for action, urging President Biden to address concerns over Ukraine strategy and immigration policy changes. White House budget director Shalanda Young warns that U.S. aid for Ukraine will run out by the end of the year. House Republicans, under Johnson's leadership, pass a bill providing security assistance only for Israel, coupled with cuts to the IRS budget. The impasse on funding could result in Russia gaining an advantage in ongoing conflict
articles.title: 'Putin could win': Johnson slams Biden's Ukraine funding strategy

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: FBI Director Christopher Wray testified on Tuesday before the Senate Judiciary Committee expressing deep concerns about the unprecedented level of terror threats facing the United States since the October 7 attack on Israel. Wray highlighted the unique and alarming situation in the current "threat matrix." In a related development, he urged the Senate committee to renew the authority of the U.S. government for warrantless surveillance outside the country.
articles.title: FBI director warns of unprecedented terror threats

articles.description: WASHINGTON: US President Joe Biden's popularity was near its lowest level of his presidency this month, a sign of the challenges ahead for his re-elec.
articles.title: Biden approval near lowest level of his presidency

articles.description: Saudi Arabia offers tax incentives to foreign companies locating regional headquarters in the kingdom, including a 30-year exemption for corporate income tax. The move is part of efforts by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman to diversify the economy and create new industries. The tax exemption package includes a zero percent income tax rate for regional entities and withholding tax on approved activities for 30 years. The program has attracted 200 foreign companies so far, and Saudi Arabia looks forward to welcoming more international companies to participate in projects and major events.
articles.title: Saudi Arabia offers tax breaks for companies moving regional HQs to Riyadh

articles.description: Rest of World News: GENEVA: Countries need to increase their taxes on alcohol and sugar-sweetened beverages, the World Health Organization said Tuesday, saying too few st.
articles.title: WHO says time to hike alcohol, sugary drinks tax

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Despite an overall decrease in juvenile cases, young people in the Twin Cities are engaging in a growing number of severe crimes, including auto thefts, gun possession, assault, robbery, and homicides involving juveniles. Hennepin County Sheriff Dawanna Witt expressed deep concern, stating that the nature of these crimes goes beyond petty theft. Local leaders are addressing this trend through a panel that aims to enhance how state and county agencies assist young individuals charged with crimes.
articles.title: Alarming surge in serious juvenile crimes grips Minneapolis–Saint Paul

articles.description: LONDON: Lawyers for Prince Harry on Tuesday began a legal challenge over his security arrangements in the UK, after he quit frontline royal duties and.
articles.title: Prince Harry in UK court battle over security

articles.description: US News: WASHINGTON: US employers posted 8.
articles.title: US job openings fall to lowest level since March 2021 as labor market cools

articles.description: Malala Yousafzai condemns Taliban rule in Afghanistan, calling it a gender apartheid that has made girlhood illegal. She highlights the negative impact on Afghan girls who are denied education, leading to depression, drug use, and suicide attempts. Malala urges the international community to recognize gender apartheid as a crime against humanity and include it in a new UN treaty on crimes against humanity. She emphasizes the need to draw attention to the treatment of women and girls in Afghanistan, which has been overshadowed by crises in other parts of the world.
articles.title: Taliban rule 'made girlhood illegal', says Malala

articles.description: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky appeals to US senators for support ahead of funding showdown with Russia. White House warns that aid will run out by the end of the year. Zelenskyy's address highlights the importance of defending democracy and preventing Putin from winning the war. Zelenskyy's chief of staff, defense minister, and speaker of Ukraine's parliament engage in a lobbying effort in Washington. Senate Republicans condition their support for funding on immigration reforms, which Democrats have rejected.
articles.title: Zelenskyy to appeal to US senators ahead of vote on Ukraine aid

articles.description: Zambia's president remains hopeful as rescue efforts continue for at least 25 informal miners trapped in a mudslide at Seseli Mine. The mine was previously owned by Vedanta's Konkola Copper Mines (KCM) but is now under the control of a local company. The miners were trapped in three locations and heavy rains have flooded the pit. The government is working to save the lives of the trapped miners, with rescue workers being cautious due to soft ground.
articles.title: Zambia's president hopeful that trapped miners still alive

articles.description: Europe News: BUDAPEST: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban will meet French President Emmanuel Macron in Paris on Thursday, his press chief said, ahead of an EU .
articles.title: Hungary's Orban to meet Macron ahead of EU summit

articles.author: TOI World Desk
articles.description: Trevor D. Jacob, a YouTuber known for staging a plane crash, has been sentenced to prison for obstructing the investigation. He intentionally crashed his plane for his YouTube channel, misleading investigators and removing the wreckage. The U.S. Attorney's Office stated that Jacob's motive was to gain notoriety and make money. Jacob's sentencing was handed down by Judge John F. Walter. His YouTube video contributed to his FAA pilot license revocation.
articles.title: YouTuber lands in jail for staging plane crash in California for views

articles.description: U.N. chief António Guterres invoked a rarely used power to press the Security Council to “avert a humanitarian catastrophe” as he reiterated his appeal for a cease-fire.

articles.description:
Brushing the dust from his hat and lying on the floor inside his home, Ali Shadilov recalls how he and other fishermen used to laugh at town elders who warned that the enormous sea they relied on was disappearing. 

“Everyone laughed and said that it would take several million years,” said Shadilov, 73, one of the last surviving former fishermen of the Aral Sea. “Back then, no one could imagine that the sea would dry up.”

The Aral Sea was once the world's fourth-largest inland body of water, with some 68,000 square kilometers (26,300 square miles). Colossal steel ships sailed on deep blue water filled with sturgeon, catfish and other species that were caught, canned and shipped across the Soviet Union. 

___

EDITORS’ NOTE: This is the first piece in an AP series on the once-massive Aral Sea, the lives of those who’ve lived and worked on its shores, and the effects of climate change and restoration efforts in the region. The AP visited both sides of the Aral, in Uzbekistan and...
articles.title: How the Aral Sea is a reminder of lost livelihoods

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The UK government and the United States on Thursday accused Russian security services of engaging in a sustained cyber-espionage campaign against top politicians, journalists and NGOs.
articles.title: UK, US accuse Russia of cyber-espionage campaign against top politicians

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Arch-foes Armenia and Azerbaijan said Thursday they would exchange prisoners of war and work towards normalising their relations, in a joint statement hailed by the EU as a "breakthrough".
articles.title: Armenia, Azerbaijan agree to exchange POWs, take steps on normalising ties

articles.author: Marc DAOU
articles.description: Abdel Fattah al-Sisi is the front-runner in Egypt’s upcoming presidential election which will be held from December 10-12. Despite being marked by a widespread crackdown on dissent and a weak economic and security record, the former army chief’s ten-year rule may be extended until 2030. It's an outcome that many believe is already written in stone.
articles.title: Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi looks to extend iron-fisted rule after ten years in power

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Activists on Thursday petitioned a French court to change the name of a neighbourhood and street in the seaside resort town of Biarritz over its racist connotations.
articles.title: French activists urge Biarritz district to drop 'racist' name

articles.author: Marc PERELMAN
articles.description: In an interview with FRANCE 24, former Ukrainian president Petro Poroshenko (2014-2019) reacted to the US Senate withholding a major package of financial and military aid for Kyiv. Poroshenko warned that the coming days are among "the most important in Ukrainian history" and undoubtedly for the world. He called it "absolutely unacceptable" that Ukraine can be the "hostage" of other issues such as internal politics ahead of next year's US presidential elections.
articles.title: US withholding aid to Ukraine 'unacceptable’, ex-president Poroshenko says

articles.description: A mother was filmed in Gaza on December 1, holding the body of her dead son in her arms after he was killed in the latest wave of Israeli bombardments. However, once the footage was uploaded online, several people and a prominent Israeli paper claimed that the dead infant was just a doll. They were wrong – we learned details about the child’s identity and spoke to forensic specialists who confirmed the images did show the remains of a human infant. This is part of a trend among pro-Israeli users to claim that images from Gaza have been staged.
articles.title: Claims that a dead baby in Gaza is actually a doll are proven false

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: The United States announced joint military flight drills in Guyana on Thursday as soaring tensions over a contested oil-rich region with neighbour Venezuela prompted the UN Security Council to call an urgent meeting.
articles.title: US to hold military exercises with Guyana amid border tensions with Venezuela

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Denmark's parliament on Thursday adopted a law criminalising the "inappropriate treatment" of religious texts, effectively banning Koran burnings after a series of desecrations of Islam's holy book sparked anger in Muslim countries over the summer.
articles.title: Denmark adopts law banning burning of Koran and other holy texts

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: French President Emmanuel Macron meets Prime Minister Viktor Orban on Thursday in a bid to break the deadlock ahead of an EU summit after the Hungarian leader threatened to block further backing for Ukraine.
articles.title: Macron hosts Hungary's Orban in bid to unlock EU support for Ukraine

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: France's Sports Minister Amelie Oudea-Castera on Thursday ruled out any move of Olympic surfing events away from Tahiti after environmental damage occurred during tests last week.
articles.title: French minister rules out relocating Tahiti's Olympic surfing events despite reef damage

articles.author: Marc PERELMAN
articles.description: In an interview with FRANCE 24, the UN high commissioner for human rights expressed deep concern about the humanitarian situation in the Gaza Strip, describing the situation as "apocalyptic". Volker Türk denounced "grave breaches of international humanitarian law" in Gaza, citing the Israeli blockade of the territory and the use of explosives in densely populated areas. Asked if Israel was deliberately targeting civilians in Gaza, Türk said "the facts speak for themselves".
articles.title: Situation in Gaza is 'apocalyptic', UN human rights chief tells FRANCE 24

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: The address on the invitation to the winner of this year's Nobel Peace Prize to attend the awards ceremony says it all. "Ms Narges Mohammadi, c/o Evin Prison, Tehran province, Iran".

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: As Senate Republicans blocked the advance of tens of billions of dollars in military and economic assistance for Ukraine Wednesday, President Joe Biden berated their tactics as “stunning" and dangerous. Yet he also signaled an openness to what GOP lawmakers ultimately want: border policy changes.
articles.title: Biden willing to 'compromise' on US border policy as Senate Republicans block Ukraine aid

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan travels to Athens on Thursday in a keenly watched visit billed as an attempted "new chapter" between the NATO allies and historic rivals after years of tension.

articles.author: FRANCE 24
articles.description: Heavy urban combat raged throughout Gaza on Thursday with some of the war’s most intensive fighting so far reported in the Jabaliya refugee camp in the north and Khan Younis in the south. Aid groups warned that Gazans are running out of places to flee as Israeli strikes were also reported in the southern border town of Rafah. Follow our live blog for all the latest developments. All times are Paris time (GMT+1).

articles.description: Moscow police carried out raids on nightclubs hosting LGBTQ events on December 1, just two days after Russia’s Supreme Court banned the “international LGBTQ movement” and classified it as an extremist movement. The police forced people in attendance to strip to their underclothes and took photos of their identity cards in what’s being described by activists as an “act of intimidation”.

articles.description: Iranian authorities have used rape and sexual assault to punish or silence those arrested during the 2022 Mahsa Amini protests, Amnesty International said in a report released on Wednesday. articles.description: French police conducted identity checks on a "massive" scale in 2021, despite not having a doctrine to define their objectives or good practice during such checks, France's public audit office, the Cour des comptes, said in a report on Wednesday.

articles.description: In an interview with FRANCE 24, Venezuela's opposition leader Maria Corina Machado said that Sunday's referendum in Venezuela over the status of the disputed region of Essequibo was "absolutely not" the success proclaimed by the Maduro regime. Asked about the political situation in Venezuela, she said the Maduro regime was "in its weakest position ever" and that she expected to "face Maduro and defeat him" in the 2024 presidential elections.

articles.author: Matthew Chapman
articles.description:
Donald Trump Jr. erupted in a profanity-filled tirade against Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin on social media on Thursday evening, demanding an end to U.S. support for Ukraine against Russian aggression.
Trump Jr.'s remarks came in response to a right-wing account saying that former Fox News anchor Tucker Carlson "confirm[ed]" that Austin warned "your uncles, cousins and sons" might be sent to fight in Russia if Ukraine didn't get the funding it needs.
"How about Go F--k Yourself!!!" wrote Trump Jr. "America doesn't need to keep funding an endless war with no path to victory."
He continued:
"If NATO is worried about Russia encroaching on NATO maybe they should be funding more of this but as always they let America do all the funding while they get virtually all the benefit. No more big wars no more funding the military industrial complex!"
Trump's eldest son added that, "For those of you who are idiots Ukraine lost this war quite some time ago we're just keeping them on life-support with never ending money!"
As of now, the battle lines in Ukraine appear to have reached a relative stalemate, with neither side making substantial breakthroughs and Russia frozen with Crimea and portions of eastern Ukraine still under their control.
ALSO READ: Nazis bullied a conservative Tennessee town. Locals punched back. Trump should be worried.
With current U.S. funding for Ukraine running out, Congress is locked in an impasse over how to get a new package of Ukraine aid, coupled with aid to Israel in their fight against Hamas, approved in the Senate.
Republicans are demanding that the aid be paired with new border controls, including some that could reduce legal immigration. Democratic lawmakers have fiercely resisted this, although President Joe Biden has signaled he's open to a compromise on some of the issues.
articles.title: 'No more big wars!' Trump's son loses it in obscenity-laden rant against defense secretary

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
Sen. Rick Scott (R-FL) is sounding the alarm on communist garlic, The Cato Institute's Scott Lincicome pointed out Thursday. 
The Republican sent a letter to Washington, D.C. secretary of commerce Gina Raimondo pointing out that the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 gives the Commerce Secretary the power to investigate imports that could be national security threats — and that garlic from China is one of them.
"I write to request such an investigation into imports from Communist China of all grades of garlic, whole or separated into constituent cloves, whether or not peeled, chilled, fresh, frozen, provisionally preserved or packed in water or other natural substance, and the threat they pose to U.S. national security," Scott wrote in his letter. 
"Food safety and security is an existential emergency that poses grave threats to our national security, public health and economic prosperity."
ALSO READ: A neuroscientist explains how Donald Trump exploits the minds of conspiracy theorists
He doesn't give any specific security cause for concern from the bulbs.
The website Spices Inc and a report by USA Today says most of the garlic sold in the U.S. comes from China —  more than 60%.
Of domestic garlic, The California Farmland Trust says that 90 percent of commercial garlic comes from that state.
articles.title: GOP Sen. sounds alarm about national security risk posed by garlic from 'communist China'

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description:
Denmark has introduced legislation to make the burning of the Koran or other religious writings illegal in future. The Danish parliament passed the new law on Thursday. 
Under its provisions the inappropriate treatment of writings with essential religious significance for recognized religious communities will be punishable by up to two years in prison. 
For example, it will also be a criminal offense to burn or stamp on the Bible or the Torah in public.
articles.title: Denmark outlaws burning the Koran and other religious books

Johnson, prime minister between 2019 and 2022, faced a second day of questioning which examined the weeks before the country's second national lockdown in November 2020. Asked whether he had wanted to allow the virus to "let rip", and about suggestions that he believed older people had reached their time, Johnson said: "No, no, no, this is all rubbish". The inquiry has heard evidence fro...
articles.title: Former UK PM Johnson denies he wanted to let COVID 'rip'

Campbell made the comments about new 20-year funding programs for the Federated States of Micronesia (FSM), the Marshall Islands (RMI) and Palau awaiting congressional approval while testifying at a Senate hearing on his nomination to become the Biden administration's next deputy secretary of state.

articles.description: By Howard Goller JERUSALEM (Reuters) - Two months into a war with Hamas, the faces of Israelis taken hostage to Gaza still appear on individual posters plastered across Jerusalem bus stops and flashed across buildings. The sombre mood was all-consuming on Thursday at the start of Hanukkah, the first Jewish festival since Oct. 7 when Israel says Hamas massacred 1,200 people. It was a solemn moment for all of Israel and not only for families of the 138 Israelis still held hostage. For some Israelis, the feeling is of a country shrinking. Some 200,000 Israelis have been uprooted from both the sou...
articles.title: Hanukkah in wartime: Israelis take stock two months on

Officials said the two events were unrelated, as the cocaine offloaded by the Coast Guard was seized over the past two months, while the alleged c...

articles.description: By Raphael Satter WASHINGTON (Reuters) -Unidentified governments are surveilling smartphone users via their apps' push notifications, a U.S. senator warned on Wednesday. In a letter to the Department of Justice, Senator Ron Wyden said foreign officials were demanding the data from Alphabet's Google and Apple. Although details were sparse, the letter lays out yet another path by which governments can track smartphones. Apps of all kinds rely on push notifications to alert smartphone users to incoming messages, breaking news, and other updates. These are the audible "dings" or visual indicators ...

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
A fellow actor filed a sexual assault complaint against Gérard Depardieu in September, prosecutors said Wednesday, adding to a string of allegations targeting the French star.
Helene Darras said that Depardieu assaulted her while filming a movie in 2007, Paris prosecutors said, confirming a report from broadcaster France 2.
Investigators were studying the complaint, which likely falls under France's statute of limitations, to decide whether or not to launch a probe.
Depardieu's lawyer Christian Saint-Palais could not immediately be reached for comment.
Darras told France 2 that Depardieu groped her when she was aged 26 and appearing as an extra in the film "Disco".
The older man "ran his hand over my thighs and my buttocks" then "said straight out: 'Do you want to come to my dressing room?'," she added.
Darras rejected the alleged advances, but "that didn't change anything," she went on. "He kept groping me between takes".
Depardieu was in 2020 charged in Paris after allegations of rapes and sexual assaults following a complaint by actor Charlotte Arnould.
Other women have since accused Depardieu of sexual violence in the press.
He insisted that he is "neither a rapist nor a predator" in a letter to conservative newspaper Le Figaro in October.
"Never, but never have I abused a woman," Depardieu wrote, saying that he would not be getting involved in "any projects" given the "context" of the allegations.
(AFP)
articles.title: French film star Depardieu faces new allegation of sexual assault

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
The United States charged four pro-Russian soldiers with war crimes on Wednesday for the abduction and torture of an American national in Ukraine.
Attorney General Merrick Garland said the charges against the four "Russia-affiliated military personnel" were the first to be brought under the US war crimes statute.
"As the world has witnessed the horrors of Russia's brutal invasion of Ukraine, so has the United States Department of Justice," Garland said. "The Justice Department will work for as long as it takes to pursue accountability and justice for Russia's war of aggression."
According to the indictment, two of those charged -- Suren Seiranovich Mkrtchyan, 45, and Dmitry Budnik -- were commanding officers of military units of the "Russian Armed Forces and/or the so-called Donetsk People…
articles.title: U.S. charges four pro-Russian troops in Ukraine with war crimes

articles.description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The U.S. has charged four Russia-affiliated soldiers with war crimes against an American carried out during Moscow's invasion of Ukraine, in what the Justice Department described as the first-ever charges under the U.S. war crimes statute. The 9-page war crime indictment against the four Russian men includes allegations of torture, inhuman treatment, conspiracy to commit war crimes and unlawful treatment of an American citizen. "As the world has witnessed the horrors of Russia’s brutal invasion of Ukraine, so has the United States Department of Justice," Attorney General ...
articles.title: US charges four Russia-affiliated soldiers with war crimes

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description:
Russian President Vladimir Putin arrived in the United Arab Emirates on Wednesday for a brief visit to the Gulf. 
The Russian president was greeted in Abu Dhabi by Emirati President Mohammed bin Sajid, the country's state news agency WAM announced on X. Putin plans to travel to Saudi Arabia later on to meet with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. 
Putin praised the bilateral relationship between the countries as historically unprecedented and invited Sajid to attend the 2024 BRICS summit in Kazan, according to Russian information.
articles.title: Putin visits United Arab Emirates on rare foreign trip

articles.author: Deutsche Presse-Agentur
articles.description:
Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan has warned Israeli authorities not to pursue Hamas members on Turkish territory. 
"If they dare to take such a step against Turkey, they will pay the price in a way that they will not be able to recover," Erdoğan told reporters on his return flight from Qatar. 
Erdoğan's remarks were carried by his communication office in response to a question on reported Israeli intelligence service plans to assassinate Hamas members abroad.
articles.title: Erdoğan: Israel will 'pay a price' if they pursue Hamas in Turkey

articles.author: M.L. Nestel
articles.description:
There may not be another Trump presidency if contenders against him take the fight to him. But if he wins the nomination and bests President Joe Biden, there are enough protections to ward off authoritarian rule. 
Trump's former National Security Advisor John Bolton appearing on CNN's "The Source" with Kaitlan Collins made it clear that he has "faith in constitutional structures" and even said that "they're strong."
So strong that they will likely come out on top of Trump's bid. 
"It will be a tremendous battle," Bolton conceded, but he believes "Trump and his acolytes will be defeated." 
He suggested that other candidates beyond former New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and former Arkansas Gov.  Asa Hutchinson need to take on the former president more often rather than throw daggers at each o…
articles.title: 'Tripping over his shoelaces': John Bolton explains how Trump can be beaten

articles.author: Matthew Chapman
articles.description:
After months of mounting pressure and frustration among both lawmakers and the military brass, Sen. Tommy Tuberville (R-AL) is finally ending his protest block on over 400 military appointments and promotions, letting them all be confirmed by voice vote. He continues to hold a block on just 11 four-star generals, who could be scheduled and confirmed individually by the Senate.
Speaking to CNN congressional reporter Manu Raju, Tuberville admitted he gave up because if he waited any longer, the nominations would have been returned to the White House, causing even further chaos.
"I can’t win. I’m still thinking about the unborn, I’m thinking about the military people that need to be promoted, it’s been a year for a lot of them. It’s been a long time," said Tuberville. "I think we proved a poi…
articles.title: 'I can't win': Tuberville reveals why he gave up on his military blockade

articles.description: By Nandita Bose BOSTON (Reuters) - U.S. President Joe Biden said on Tuesday that Hamas had repeatedly raped women and mutilated their bodies during its Oct.7 assault on southern Israel, citing survivors and witnesses of the attacks. Speaking at a political fundraiser in Boston, Biden said accounts of "unimaginable cruelty" had been shared over the past few weeks. "Reports of women raped — repeatedly raped — and their bodies being mutilated while still alive, of women's corpses being desecrated, Hamas terrorists inflicting as much pain and suffering on women and girls as possible and then murde...
articles.title: Biden says Hamas raped, mutilated women during Israel assault

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
The widow of a French serial killer known as the "Ogre of the Ardennes" on Tuesday admitted she played an "unforgivable" role in the 1990 rape and murder of British student Joanna Parrish by her former husband.
Confronted with images of Parrish's swollen face after her body was pulled from the river Yonne, Monique Olivier said that "it's because of me she's gone, it's unforgivable".
She remained silent in the glass-screened dock for long moments as she looked at the pictures, before pushing them away with a trembling hand.
Olivier is on trial for her role in three kidnappings and murders by her late husband Michel Fourniret and her role in rapes and attempted rape in two of the cases.
On "hunts" with her husband, Olivier said during cross-examination that "I was the dog, I was never anythi…
articles.title: Killer's wife says role in British student's death 'unforgivable'

articles.author: Agence France-Presse
articles.description:
Lawyers for Prince Harry on Tuesday began a legal challenge over his security arrangements in the UK, after he quit frontline royal duties and moved to North America. 
The case about his loss of UK taxpayer-funded protection is the latest in a string of court proceedings initiated by Harry, whose father is King Charles III.
Harry is taking legal action against the UK interior ministry over a February 2020 decision by a committee that deals with the security of members of the royal family. 
The Duke of Sussex, as he is formally known, had been told he would no longer be given the "same degree" of personal protective security that he previously enjoyed.
Shaheed Fatima, for Harry, told the High Court in London the case was about the prince's right to "safety and security". 
She added in writt…
articles.title: Prince Harry in U.K. court battle over security

articles.author: Abe Silberstein
articles.description:
Assuming Israel succeeds in breaking Hamas’ political hold on the Gaza Strip, the postwar priorities for Israel and the United States are likely to revolve around reconstruction of the strip and a renegotiation of the relationship between Israel and the Palestinian Authority. Since taking office in January 2021, the Joseph R. Biden administration has deprioritized final status negotiations between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization. President Biden and his team concluded, likely correctly, that there was not much chance of success. They also believed, incorrectly, that the conflict was being successfully “managed” by Israel. Today, however, senior administration officials, including
The post After Israel Defeats Hamas, the United States Should Recognize Palestine appeared first on War on the Rocks.
articles.title: After Israel Defeats Hamas, the United States Should Recognize Palestine

articles.author: Bill Matory
articles.description:
The fall is an ideal time for a visit to Taipei — as the military planners for the People’s Republic of China plotting a cross-strait invasion know all too well. Weather and ocean states in October, much like in March through April, provide Beijing a favorable window to attempt an invasion of Taiwan. This October, American and Japanese forces conducted an operationally focused bilateral exercise, rehearsing missions that would have been unthinkable a few short years ago but that now prove vital when deterring Chinese aggression. Resolute Dragon 23.2 not only demonstrated each force’s lethality and interoperability but also strengthened
The post Resolute Dragon: Reassurance, Deterrence, and a Call for Coordination appeared first on War on the Rocks.

articles.author: David Barno
articles.description:
The U.S. military spends untold time, energy, and effort preparing for its future wars. Yet periodically, real wars intrude to shatter hypothetical concepts and show how the ever-changing interaction of doctrine, technology, and leadership affects the character of war. The conflicts raging today in Ukraine and Gaza offer tragic examples of two markedly different kinds of modern wars — one largely a conventional battle between states raging across thousands of kilometers of disputed territory, and the other an unconventional clash between a terrorist group and a state battling in a cramped and densely populated urban area. Although it is still
The post Learning from Real Wars: Gaza and Ukraine appeared first on War on the Rocks.
articles.title: Learning from Real Wars: Gaza and Ukraine
